Title: the holiday summation

Penny: Hey, can you help me put some of the food out?
Yeah, but he doesn’t live here anymore.
Hi. Welcome back. How was Texas?
Well, you’re home now.
I told him to take it down. He would not listen to me.
So, what happened in Texas that was so bad?
Do boys have flowers?
Mm.
Oh, boy, I think it’s about to get bad.
What?
That’s too loud.
Hi. There’s the little family!
Mm.
Yeah. Go ahead.
Oh, it’s no problem, Amy and Sheldon were just telling us about their trip to Texas.
Stop. Okay. They told Mary they were living together, there was a fight, he got his feelings hurt, then he put underwear on his head.
Okay. Then what happened?
So tell me, how did Sheldon look with an earring?
Actually, we got in a pretty nasty fight.
To be fair, we may have been on edge because of the Christmas tree.
You do make a cute elf.
Hey, hey, I just found a farm where they let you chop down your own tree.
No, what’s stupid is a physicist who doesn’t understand when you swing an axe, you don’t let go.
Ugh. It’s 70 degrees, you didn’t need mittens.
Yes, yes, you bruise, you peel. It’s like I’m married to an old piece of fruit.
Fine.
Leonard?
There’s something on the windshield.
You need a break?
There’s no shame in asking for a break.
Ugh. Leonard?
There’s a tree on you.
Yeah, with gasoline and a match? Sure.
You poor things you must be exhausted.
So things started to turn around?
I can’t believe you fit in the crib.
Our pleasure.
Leonard: Yeah. Let me finish packing this stuff up. You know how Sheldon is if he sees Christmas stuff lying around after New Year’s.
Well, he doesn’t live at Walmart, but he still threw a tantrum when he saw Marshmallow Peeps after Easter. And that’s the same man who complains you can’t find Marshmallow Peeps after Easter.
Well, he didn’t throw up on the baby. That’s a win.
Did you at least have a good flight down there?
And before our next drive to Comic-Con, I need the name of that juice.
Hold on. How did you get him in the car?
Who knows what he has down there.
Absolutely not.
Absolutely not.
Hey.
And their Sherpas.
On purpose, not the way it used to happen in high school.
It might’ve been the worst one we’ve ever had.
Well, we had started binge-watching Luke Cage together, and it was kind of our thing, and then I find out that she watched two episodes without me.
Oh, yeah? And you thought Spock ears were only good for Comic-Con.
Oh cool, I’ll be like a pointy-eared Paul Bunyan.
Stupid idea.
For the tenth time, my mittens were slippery!
You know how easily I blister.
Look, we could keep fighting and let it ruin our night, or, or we can stop and try to salvage the evening.
Thank you.
Yeah.
Do not need a break.
If I need a break, I’ll ask for a break.
Yeah?
You want to decorate it tonight?
By the way, if anyone asks, the elevator shaft always had a tree in it.
Ignore him. How did you get the baby to stop crying?
Please tell me you didn’t use Amy’s magic juice.
See you guys at work.
Penny (checking phone): Oh. It’s Bernadette. She says they’re running late. The baby threw up on Howard, and then Howard threw up on Howard.
Sheldon: Hello.
Oh, you know., the lone star state. Hmm. That should be its Yelp rating.
Yeah. It is good to be home. Oh, good lord, is that mistletoe? Don’t you maniacs own a calendar?
It was fine. Other than the weird-tasting juice Amy gave me, I slept the whole way.
Well, we were on our way to my mother’s house…
How did we get in the car?
Do we have to? I really don’t want to hear the religious lecture.
There’s always one. She gave it to my sister about her boyfriend, my brother about his girlfriend, my father about his girlfriend. That one had some un-Christian words in it.
Eh, I don’t know. I am her precious little boy. And you did take my flower.
Anyway…
Given that your hands prepared it, isn’t that a little self-serving?
Welcome to Texas.
Oh, wait, wait, shouldn’t we just eat? You know, I mean, God did take time out of his busy schedule to bless these Sloppy Joes.
All right. This is on you. Amy and I are living together in sin, like a couple of New Yorkers. Now, while you scold us, I’m going to get a knife and a fork. Joe may be sloppy, but Sheldon’s not.
What? Wh, where’s the judgment? Wh, where’s the fire and brimstone? Where’s the part where you tell us we’re going to Hell and I say have you seen the size of the bugs outside? We’re already there.
And what special circumstances are those?
What, so you thought I was going to be alone for the rest of my life?
Well, this is highly insulting.
I’m the child she was worried about? I have a brother and sister whose combined intellectual wattage couldn’t power a potato clock, if I spotted them the potato.
Well, I was in my room, I couldn’t hear what they were saying.
Just being the unsocialised eccentric my mother always thought I was.
Yeah. And I don’t understand why you’re taking her side. By being my girlfriend, she’s saying you’re a weirdo, too.
And?
Can you believe my mother thinks we’re both strange?
Well, first we buttered my feet to get the swim fins off, and then we went out.
You’re right. I have Leonard and Howard and Raj, Stuart, Penny, Leonard’s mom, Bernadette, Wil Wheaton…
I was going chronologically. You’re right between Koothrappali’s father and Omar, the one-eyed Sparkletts guy.
I knew we should’ve never mentioned us living together in the first place.
Disagree. We’ve known about evolution since 1859, she still believes in Noah and his amazing zoo boat. This could have all been avoided if you’d only listened to me.
Why would you do that?
You managed the situation?
So my mother thought I was incapable of finding a mate, and my mate thinks I’m incapable of running my own life.
I have gotten much better at that.
What? How should I know? Excited? Itchy? Give me the first letter.
How would you feel if I contacted your mother behind your back?
Delighted? What., not if I guessed for a hundred years.
Yeah. Here. I’ll catch you up.
How did we get in the car?
I was acting odd intentionally.

Well, there’s really not much left to tell. I decided that my mother views me as a child because I never went through a rebellious phase, so, I got an earring. (Flashback to Sheldon screaming.) My mother made me take it out. (Flashback to Sheldon screaming.) Amy put alcohol on it. (Flashback to Sheldon screaming.) And here we are.
I don’t understand what’s wrong with socks.
So Bernadette, if I express interest in your baby will you promise not to make me touch it?
Hey, how’s life with your baby?
To this day I’ve never touched Stuart.
Wait, so how does the story end? Is the baby a jerk or is Bernadette a bad mother?
What? Is there another twist coming? Is the baby not theirs at all?
It says here that up to 80% of new mothers experience baby blues. And that the best thing to do is reassure them that they’re doing a good job. Bernadette, you are doing a good job.
Thank you, Internet. I’m telling you, with the right YouTube video, I can give Howard a vasectomy.
Oh. A small human wreaks havoc on his wife’s genitals and he gets time off.
Amy: Hi.
It was not a great trip.
I rented one of those carts, pushed him toward the open door and just let inertia take care of the rest.
So, while we’re at your mother’s house, it might be a good time to tell her that we’re living together.
Maybe there won’t be one.
Well, she likes me. You know, there’s a chance she might be okay with it.
Thank you for cooking, it looks delicious.
Well, uh, Howard and Bernadette had their baby.
They haven’t said. Anyway, we, uh, we also have some exciting news to share.
Sheldon, don’t overreact.
Blah, blah, blah, blah, blah.
I’ll take over from here.
He’s been in there a long time. Should I go talk to him?
Are you going to?
Sheldon, what, what are you doing?
We’re ignoring the fins, okay.
I don’t think that’s what she’s saying.
That’s exactly what she was saying.
Well, after that, Sheldon and I got out of the house for a while.
You know, I’m sorry your mother made you feel bad. But, you know, at the end of the day, she was wrong, because you’re not alone.
What about the woman who just buttered your big flat feet?
Well, let’s try to not let it ruin the rest of our trip.
She was gonna find out eventually.
Sheldon, I knew your mother was fine with us living together because I already told her we were.
This was a potential issue, so I got out ahead of it and I managed the situation for you.
That’s right.
Not your whole life. I mean, science, you got that. Organizing your sock drawer, you’re the king. But understanding how other people are feeling, that’s a weak spot for you.
Have you? How am I feeling right now?
You and I are in a relationship. I help you with your shortcomings, and you help me with mine.
Delighted that you showed any interest in my family at all?
Do you need help?
Like the pirate who helps the other pirates connect to the Internet.
Really? You’re never gonna touch their baby?
Sheldon.
That was fun, thank you.
Mary: Thank you, God, for the food we are about to receive and for the nourishment of our bodies and bless the hands that prepared it. Amen.
You start changing the words to the prayers, next thing you know, you’re in a church with a guitar.
Oh, it’s my pleasure. Mm. I’m so glad y’all could make it. So, tell me, what’s going on back home?
Oh, that’s wonderful. Now, have they decided to raise it Jewish or regular?
Come on, Shelly, tell me your news.
Well, thank you for letting me know, and I, for one, am thrilled.
Obviously, I would prefer if you weren’t living out of wedlock, but given your special circumstances, I’m very happy for you.
Shelly, how do I put this? By your third birthday, you had memorized over a thousand different kinds of trains, and I never imagined a woman getting aboard any of them.
No. Just for the middle part. ‘Cause at the end I assumed there’d be nurses.
Blah, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah.
He’s upset with me. I should be the one who talks to him.
You startin’ to see why I didn’t go in there? Sheldon, if you’re trying to prove me wrong, the tighty-whities on your head ain’t changing my mind.
Bernadette: Really? So you can control it?
I couldn’t explain it if I tried.
It’s like I was excited for a present and got socks.
It’s been wonderful, Sheldon, thanks for asking.
Oh, please stop crying, I’m begging you. I don’t know what else to do. My boobs are empty. Do you want lasagna? Shh, shh, shh, it’s okay, it’s okay. Shh. What have we done?
It took me two hours to get her down.
No they’re not, you bozo. How come Stuart can get her to stop crying, but I can’t?
Everyone’s a better mom than me.
How can she hate me? I make her food in my chest. It’s like hating a frozen yogurt machine.
Thank you, Sheldon, I’m feeling better now.
Yeah, eventually I figured out how to get the baby to sleep.
I didn’t know what else to do. It worked.
I think I live here now. It’s fine.
I could take a bath in the sink. I don’t, but I can.
Howard: Hey, guys.
The baby’s asleep, can we put her in your room?
No. I got it. Doubtfire, Poppins, follow me.
What did we miss?
So what did you and Leonard do?
What happened
Hey, I found superhero baby wipes, the perfect way to clean up crime, and tushies.
Hey, he got her to stop.
What’s the matter?
Oh, good.
I mean, it’s Stuart. Maybe she’s playing possum until he goes away.
It has been hard to sleep with all the crying.
She doesn’t hate you, stop saying that.
Shh, I don’t hate you.
Bernie?
Great. And where are you?
Oh. This is new.
Well, I’d say that’s thinking outside the box, but, come on.
Do you need help getting out?
Is it okay if I get some sleep?
Good job, Mommy. I’m proud of you.
Good night. I love both my girls.
Not me, paternity leave.
With pay, sucka. Forgot the baby, still new to this.
Raj: You know, in India when my baby brother cried like that, the servants would just take him far away so we couldn’t hear it. Not always, sometimes we’d leave.
Oh, he’s really good with her.
Oh, don’t take it so personally, maybe your baby’s just a jerk.
Stuart: I don’t understand how that turns into the worst fight of your life.
Oh, I just talked to her. I’ve been told the sound of my voice puts people to sleep.
Oh, thank you for asking. Uh, I, uh, went to visit my grandmother. She’s in Bakersfield. Uh, usually my brother and sister go… oh come on.
Leonard (hearing animal noises): I hope it kills us both.
